Title.evidence: We tested the hypothesis that a single cryoneurolysis treatment would decrease phantom pain 4 months later.

Trial_Design.evidence: Each received a single-injection femoral and sciatic nerve block with lidocaine and was subsequently randomized to receive either ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryoneurolysis or sham treatment at these same locations.

Participants.evidence: We enrolled patients with a lower-limb amputation and established phantom pain.

Intervention.evidence: Each received a single-injection femoral and sciatic nerve block with lidocaine and was subsequently randomized to receive either ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryoneurolysis or sham treatment at these same locations.

Objective.evidence: We tested the hypothesis that a single cryoneurolysis treatment would decrease phantom pain 4 months later.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in average phantom pain intensity between baseline and 4 months as measured with a Numeric Rating Scale (0–10).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: was subsequently randomized to receive either ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryoneurolysis or sham treatment at these same locations.

Blinding.evidence: Investigators, participants, and clinical staff were masked to treatment group assignment with the exception of the treating physician performing the cryoneurolysis who had no subsequent participant interaction.

Number_Randomised.evidence: n=71 for active treatment and n=73 for sham.

Number_Analysed.evidence: n=71 for active treatment and n=73 for sham.

Result_Outcome.evidence: After 4 months, pain intensity decreased by 0.5 [−0.5, 3.0] in patients given cryoneurolysis (n=71) versus 0 [0, 3] in patients given sham (n=73): estimated difference (95% CI) −0.1 (−1.0, 0.7), P=0.759.

Harms.evidence: One serious adverse event occurred following a protocol deviation in which a femoral nerve cryolesion was induced just below the inguinal ligament—instead of the sensory-only saphenous nerve—which resulted in quadriceps weakness, and possibly a fall and clavicle fracture.
